body.p: Sung by Mr Turnbull, as Maclymore, in the Reprisal.22 The Reprisal, written by the Scottish novelist and playwright Tobias Smollett, was first performed at the Theater Royal, Drury Lane in 1757. Presumably this song was written for a performance in the Dumfries theater.

note.a: Tune, “Woe’s my heart that we shou’d sunder.”
note.note: 3 The air is given in Robert Chambers, The Songs of Scotland Prior to Burns with the Tunes (Edinburgh: W. & R. Chambers, 1890), pp. 329-330. Chambers comments that Ramsay composed a new song “to supersede a homely one which had long possessed popular favour”: see Allan Ramsay, “With broken words and downcast eyes,” Tea Table Miscellany, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1724: Glasgow: Crum, 1871), I: pp. 79-80. Chambers also notes: “An air under the title of Alace my heart that we should sunder appears in Playford’s Collection, 1700. There is also one, essentially different from the above, in the Skene Manuscript, under the title of Alace this night that we suld sinder” (p. 331).

lg.l: When war’s alarms had reach’d our land,
And loudly roar’d the Gallic thunder;
When under George’s high command,44 That is, King George III.
My heart for glory burn’d like tinder:
I held my lassie by the hand,
Her gushing tears were like to blind her;
And as we parted on the strand,
She cry’d, “My dearest, must we sunder.”
Far from our native hills you wander,
With thee my constant heart shall go,
By day and night although we sunder:
Till Peace her olive ensign shew,
And hush to sleep Britannia’s thunder,
For thee my tears shall ever flow,
And heave my bosom though we sunder.”
